column1: ALOG	“Arabidopsis thaliana LSH1 and Oryza G1 proteins are abbreviated with 'ALOG' and also referred to as light-dependent short hypocotyl (LSH) proteins (Lee et al.

column3: 2020). ALOG proteins are involved i.e. in the elongation of the hypocotyl
column4: in the determination of the lateral organ identity and in the conservation of the apical meristems (e.g.
column10: based on the occurrences of ALOG proteins in some streptophyte algae

column1: C2H2-IDD	"The Cys2-His2 (C2H2) zinc-finger protein family is present in all eukaryotes and among the largest families of eukaryotic transcription factors (Seetharam & Stuart
column2: 2013). One identified plant-specific subfamily of this large protein family is the Indeterminate Domain (IDD) subfamily of TFs
column3: which was first reported in Zea mays (Coelho et al.
column5: 2020). Proteins belonging to the IDD subfamily can be distinguished from the remaining C2H2 members by the fact that they contain a highly conserved N-terminal IDD domain in addition to further C2H2 zinc finger domains (Prochetto & Reinheimer
column6: 2020). Among previously identified functions controlled by C2H2-IDD proteins are metabolic and development processes like flowering time
column8: leaf differentiation and the regulation of the C4 Kranz anatomy (Coelho et al.
column13: G. W. (2013). A study on the distribution of 37 well conserved families of C2H2 zinc finger genes in eukaryotes. BMC Genomics
column16: Coelho, C. P., Huang, P., Lee, D.-Y., & Brutnell, T. P. (2018). Making Roots, Shoots, and Seeds: IDD Gene Family Diversification in Plants. Trends in Plant Science, 23(1), 66–78. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tplants.2017.09.008
column17: Prochetto, S., & Reinheimer, R. (2020). Step by step evolution of Indeterminate Domain (IDD) transcriptional regulators: from algae to angiosperms. Annals of Botany, 126(1), 85–101. https://doi.org/10.1093/aob/mcaa052	TF
